EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 

Description of Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled



Resinall QalicB (RQB") is a resin hydrogenation facility located in Hattiesburg, Mississippi. As a result of the manufacturing process, hydrogen is present at the facility at times following gas delivery, in quantities that exceed the threshold quantities specified by the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions regulations. The facility has one covered process that requires the facility to meet Program 3 requirements of the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions regulations. Hydrogen is delivered to the facility in trucks and off-loaded into a storage tank. In the process, hydrogen is used in the production of hydrogenated resins. 



B.     Accidental Release Prevention & Emergency Response Policies of Resinall



RQB is committed to protecting facility personnel, the public and the environment from any workplace and accidental release hazards. Safety, environmental protection and risk management programs are fully implemented and coordinated with community emergency responders for emergency planning and response efforts.



C.    Release Scenario Discussion



The following are brief descriptions of the release scenarios that are being submitted by RQB. RQB elected to use the EPA RMP*Comp program and the Off-site Consequence Analysis Guidance document to calculate estimated release rates and to determine the distances to the hydrogen endpoint. 



Worst-Case Release Scenario



The worst-case flammable release scenario for RQB was determined to be an instantaneous explosion of the hydrogen storage tank. A major release of this magnitude is extremely unlikely due to the advances that have taken place in storage tank design and off-loading procedures, as well as development of a rigorous maintenance and prevention programs present at the RQB facility. The EPA RMP*Comp program was used to estimate the distance to the 1.0 psi overpressure endpoint. 



Alternative Release Scenarios

The alternative release scenario for hydrogen was determined to be a fire during unloading of a delivery truck that may result in an explosion. The EPA RMP*Comp program was used to estimate the distance to the flammable endpoint. 



D.    Five-Year Accident History



Under the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions regulations, an accidental release is defined as a release of a regulated substance that "resulted in deaths, injuries or significant property damage on-site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage."  In the past five years, RQB has not had any accidents that meet the requirements of the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions regulations.



E.    Prevention Program Elements



Management System - RQB has a management program in place that assigns overall responsibility for the development and implementation of the risk management program to a qualified individual or position of responsibility. It clearly delineates accountability and responsibilities for any elements where responsibilities are delegated.



Process Safety Information - Up-to-date process safety information is maintained for use by employees operating the covered process in accordance with 40 CFR 68.48, including the following:

?    The  safety data sheet (SDS) for hydrogen that contains toxicity information, permissible exposure limits, physical data, reactivity data,   thermal and chemical stability data and synergistic effects from mixing process flows.

?    Block flow diagrams for the covered process.

?    Process chemistry and maximum intended inventory data for the covered process.

?    Safe operating limits and evaluation of consequences of deviations from these limits for the covered process.

?    Covered process equipment information consisting of materials of construction; piping and instrumentation diagrams (P&IDs); electrical classification; relief system design and design basis; ventilation system design; design code

deviations; and

?    Equipment inspections.



Training - New employees working with a covered process receive initial training in accordance with 40 CFR 68.54. The training includes an overview of the process and emphasizes process operating procedures, safe work practices, health and safety hazards, and emergency operations including shutdown. Refresher training is provided at a minimum of every three years to all employees involved in working with the covered process. Documentation is maintained for each employee to ensure that he or she received and understood the required training.



Mechanical Integrity - A maintenance program has been developed in accordance with 40 CFR 68.56 for covered process equipment. Employees involved in the maintenance of the covered processes receive additional training, which includes an overview of the process, its hazards, how to avoid or correct unsafe conditions, and in the procedures applicable to the employee's job tasks. Inspections and tests are periodically conducted on the covered process. Procedures cover generally accepted good engineering practices. The frequency of tests is consistent with manufacturer's recommendations, good engineering practices and prior operating experience. 



Management of Change - RQB has implemented written procedures to manage changes. These procedures assure that the following considerations are addressed prior to any future change:

?    The technical basis for the proposed change;

?    The impact the change will have on safety and health;

?    Modification to operating procedures that will be required;

?    The necessary time period for the change; and

?    The required authorization for the proposed change.

In addition, employees involved with operating the process, providing maintenance to process and contract employees are informed and trained prior to the start-up after the change has occurred. Process safety information and operating procedures is modified prior to the change.



PSSR - RQB per

forms a PSSR review of the hydrogenation process. This review  ensures that:

?    The construction and equipment used in the process is in accordance with design specifications.

?    Safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place and adequate.

?    The PHA has been performed and recommendations have been resolved or implemented.



Compliance Audits - Risk management program  compliance is confirmed through safety audits that are performed at least once every three years in accordance with 40 CFR 68.58. The audits are completed by at least one person knowledgeable in the process. A report of the findings is generated following the audit, and all deficiencies and/or recommendations are promptly addressed and the resolution is documented. The two most recent safety audit reports are maintained at the facility.



Incident Investigation - Specific incident investigation, reporting, and documentation procedures have been implemented and are followed in accordance with 40 CFR 68.60 in response to any incident involving a covered process that did or could have reasonably resulted in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance. Under CAPP regulations, a catastrophic release is defined as a major uncontrolled emission, fire, or explosion involving one or more regulated substances that present imminent and substantial endangerment to public health and the environment. 

The incident investigation procedure is initiated as soon as possible and no later than 48 hours following any incident. A team is established to perform the incident investigation and always includes at least one person knowledgeable in the process, a contract employee if the incident involves work by a contractor, and other persons with appropriate qualifications to investigate an accident.

Following the investigation, a written report is prepared summarizing the following information at a minimum: date of the incident; date the investigation began; description of the incident and any c

ontributing factors; and any recommendations resulting from the investigation. When completed, all affected personnel, including contract employees, are to review the report. Incident investigation reports are maintained at the facility for a minimum of five years.



Employee Participation - RQB has established has developed a written employee participation plan.



Hot Work Permits - RQB issues hot work permits for hot work operations as required by the PSM/CAPP regulations.



Contractors - RQB conducts the following to manage contractors at the facility:

?    Obtain and evaluate information regarding the contractor's safety performance and programs. 

?    Inform the contractor of the known fire or explosion hazards.

?    Explain to the contractor the applicable provisions of the response program.

?    Develop and implement safe work practices to control entrance, presence and exit of the contractors in the process area.

?    Periodically evaluate the performance of the contractors.

RQB also ensures the contractor employers are adhering to the requirements of the risk management program:

?    The contractor must assure that each contract employee trained properly

?    The contractor must assure that each contract employee is instructed about the known fire and explosion hazard of the process

?    The contractor must document that each contract employee has received the proper training

?    The contractor must assure that each contract employee follows safety rules

The contractor must advise RQB of any unique hazards presented by the contract employee.



F.    Emergency Response Program



RQB is not required to have a full emergency response plan since it meets the exemption requirements established in 40 CFR 68.90. RQB does not respond to any releases of hydrogen at the plant. 40 CFR 68.90 exempts the implementation of a full emergency response program if the owner/operator of a regulated facility whose employees do not respond to accidental releases of a regulated substance meet

the following conditions:

?    For a facility with only regulated flammable substances held in excess of the threshold quantity, must coordinate response actions with the local fire department and

?    The appropriate mechanisms are in place to notify emergency responders when there is a need for a response.



In EPA's "General Guidance for Risk Management Programs", EPA interprets "response" to be consistent with the definition under OSHA's Hazardous Work Operations and Emergency Responses (HAZWOPER) Standard. OSHA defines "emergency response" as "a response effort by employees from outside the immediate release area or by other designated responders...to an occurrence which results in or is likely to result in an uncontrolled release of a hazardous substance." The key factor is that responders are designated for such tasks by their employer. The definition excludes "responses to incidental releases of hazardous substances where the substance can be absorbed, neutralized or otherwise controlled at the time of release by employees in the immediate release area, or by maintenance personnel" as well as "responses to releases of hazardous substances where there is not potential safety hazard (i.e., fire, explosion or chemical exposure)."

RQB does not respond to any release of hydrogen. The facility coordinated response actions with the Hattiesburg Fire Department. Therefore, RQB is not required to have a detailed emergency response plan under CAPP regulations.



G.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety



RQB continuously investigates and reviews technology and / or applications that could possibly enhance its safety efforts.
